column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/11/bucky-irving-in-elite-company/|Bucky Irving In Elite Company|BY IRA KAUFMAN Jayden Daniels or Bo Nix. Bo Nix or Jayden Daniels. Everyone can identify the twin favorites to win NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year honors. Nix and Daniels are playing well under center for winning teams. That goes a long way with the 50 Associated Press voters who will turn in their ballots within a few days of the end of the regular season. As a long-time AP voter
column2: I’m impressed with how the Broncos and Commanders are faring with rookie quarterbacks. Daniels appeared to be the clear Rookie of the Year favorite until Nix raised his game for a 7-5 Broncos team that has rebounded nicely from an 0-2 start. In Tampa
column3: there’s a dynamic fourth-round draft pick who is coming off his best pro game. Whether he’s dodging a couple of defenders at the line of scrimmage or making cornerbacks looks silly after a reception
column4: Bucky Irving appears poised to lead the Bucs on another late-season surge to the playoffs. Don’t expect the 125th pick in the draft to vault ahead of Daniels or Nix for rookie honors. That’s not going to happen. He’s not a quarterback
column5: yet Irving provides weekly juice for one of the league’s elite offenses. Liam Coen has brought Irving along slowly — until now. It’s crunch time. With six games remaining
column6: the 5-6 Bucs have little margin for error. Irving received a season-high 18 touches against the Giants
column7: generating 151 yards from scrimmage on only 34 snaps. Heading into Carolina
column8: Irving’s workload should only increase in the stretch run. Why? He deserves it. You go with your best players and at the moment
column9: Bucky Irving is one of Tampa Bay’s best players. He’s averaging 5.9 yards on his 140 touches this season. The only backs with more touches and a better average are Derrick Henry (6.2)
column10: Jahmyr Gibbs (6.4) and Saquon Barkley (6.6). How’s that for company?  Irving is providing a weekly highlight reel with his sharp jump cuts and field vision. He rarely runs in a straight line and he leads all rookie backs in rushing yards and touchdowns. The kid can catch
column11: too. Irving has latched onto 32 of the 34 passes Baker Mayfield has sent his way. That 94.1 percent success rate is No. 1 in the league. No wonder Irving has rapidly gained the confidence of Mayfield
column12: Todd Bowles and the Glazers. Jason Licht might have whiffed on pass rushers in recent drafts
column13: but he hit a home run with Irving. The former Oregon standout is soft-spoken. He prefers to do his talking on the field and right now
column14: you can’t shut him up. Irving played two years for the Ducks with Nix and despite Oregon’s success
column15: some NFL scouts were concerned about Irving 5-foot-9 frame and his 4.55 clocking at the Combine. When Irving lasted until the third day of the draft
column16: the Bucs pounced. While Rachaad White has value as a pass-catching back who can block

column2: handicapper turned stathead Warren Sharp documented how
column4: sacks absolutely destroyed offensive drives. The percentage of offensive drives that ended in touchdowns without a sack was dramatically higher than drives that resulted in a touchdown despite a sack. Simply put
column5: if a defense can put a quarterback on the ground
column6: the odds were great that drive either ended in a punt or perhaps a field goal attempt. And folks actually wonder why Joe is so obsessed with an edge rush. Can you imagine? Well
column8: living proof how a sack can completely eff up a drive. And yes
column9: this intel comes from Sharp Football Analysis. Tampa Bay averages 3.06 points per drive on possessions without a sack (2nd in the NFL) compared to 0.55 points per drive with a sack (30th).
